title: Which major stock exchange index among the four "Asian Tiger" economies will perform best between 10 January 2019 and 28 June 2019?
preds: Day before- even account for recent variance, Taiwan would have to drop 300 pts, which appears very unlikely given recent trends. The only close competitor is HSI, which would have to rise beyond its near-term high of 10.5 in order to surpass Taiwan.

I got a hickup from seeing the numbers, but doing the numbers, nothing has changed. is there something monumental and predictable happening later in June? I don't get it, do you?

The fact there is correlation means that  the current order of the indexes is less likely to change. Additionally, folks using different methods e.g. @nigster have reached a similar conclusion about the relative order. I am therefore extremizing my forecast.

Simple update to reflect today's index values, which spread out nearly linearly as +3.1%, 5.1%, 9.4% and 12.4%.

Just over three weeks since my last update, and only two months to go. Singapore and South Korea are neck and neck in 4th and 3rd (indistinguishable from each other really) at +6.7% and +6.8%, and Taiwan has pulled into a slight lead at +12.8% to Hang Seng's +12.1%. My updated predictions reflect today's current reality.

According to Economic Forecast for 2019-2020 outlook, stock markets in Q3 of 2019 in those countries are predicted to be as followed (in points):
- Taiwan: 10381 (https://tradingeconomics.com/taiwan/forecast) => + 6.79%
- Singapore: 3146 (https://tradingeconomics.com/singapore/forecast) => - 1.18%
- South Korea: 2092 (https://tradingeconomics.com/south-korea/forecast) => + 1.39%
- Hongkong: 28168 (https://tradingeconomics.com/hong-kong/forecast) => + 6.21% Given the well-rounded calculating methods which take into account other macroeconomic indicators and medium-term expectations of trade, market, government, etc., these forecast figures provide a good level of certainty and reliability. Hongkong and Taiwan share a similar level of performance on their stock markets, so the likelihood of being the best equally divided. While it is very unlikely that Singapore's Strait Times Index show a positive signal in Q3 (0% of being best performer), South Korea is expected a low likelihood of beating Hongkong's and Taiwan's.

I feel that Singapore's stock exchange is less susceptible to global shocks or tremors within the global markets.
They have the best technology let alone make everything

edge to Hang Seng: bigger GDP
attracts Chinese money
ahead last year with Singapore 2nd; slighly better momentum although both economies slowing with lower prospects for miliennial wealth generation

Looking at performance to date (03/22/2019) and using the same measurement of performance that will be used performance stands at: HSI: 1.097
STI: 1.008
KOSPI: 1.059
TWSE: 1.094 In the past six months, 09/26/2018 to 03/22/2019 performance stands at: HSI: 4.66
STI: -0.74
KOSPI: -7.15
TWSE: -3.09 Looking at long term performance from 03/29/2014 to 03/22/19 performance stands at: HSI: 21.25
STI: 1.26
KOSPI: 31.94
TWSE: 10.40 HSI is the best performer since 01/10/2019, has grown in the past six months, and is the second best performer over five years.
STI has shown the slowest short and long term growth, with long term growth almost stagnant, but has been somewhat immune to recent volatility.
KOSPI has had the best long term growth, but has experienced a down turn in the past six months, and slow growth since 01/10/2019.
TWSE has moderate growth over the long term and since 01/10/2019, but has slowed in the recent six months. STI appears to be the most unlikely to perform the best between 01/10/2019, despite its performance in the past six months it has not shown recent growth, nor long term growth to the same level as other indexes.
KOSPI has the best performance over five years, but has been slow in recent months.
TWSE, by a slight margin has the best performance since 01/10/2019, but has been the third best performer over the longer terms.
HSI finishes on top in the two most recent terms and is the only index to see growth over the past six months, but is a distance behind the KOSPI over the past five years. I believe that the HSI will be the best performer baring any major market shift, if there is a significant shakeup the STI may be the best performer despite its lack of growth it has been the most level index over five years. Sources:
https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/HSI:IND
https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/FSSTI:IND
https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/KOSPI:IND
https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/TWSE:IND

Outside view: I managed to collect daily index data as far back as March 2011 (most of the data came from [1]). I generated distributions for the daily % movements in each index (using their historical averages and standard deviation) and used these distributions to construct random walks (assuming normal distributions) for each index from now (using latest closing prices) to 28 June. I repeated these random walks 10,000 times using Monte Carlo. I then compare the resulting index levels on 28 June to the starting ones from 10 January, and extract the best performing index. This provides 10,000 simulations of the best performer. The final step is to calculate frequencies of being best for each index out of these 10,000 simulated outcomes. Results: 35, 10, 36, 19 Also noting that if I just take all 6-month periods between now and March 2011 and check best performer base rates these are: 35, 19, 19, 27. This method, while interesting for curiosity sake is not ideal here because the question is asking how the indexes will perform relative to a specific date in the past. Still, interesting differences for KOSPI and TWI. Inside View:  I will address this in the future. [1] https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/%5EIXIC/history?period1=1233723600&period2=1549256400&interval=1d&filter=history&frequency=1d Tagging random walking compatriots @nigster, @petequinn, @Prognosticating-Beek in case they are interested or able to provide alternative results.

Taiwan: 9932.26 / 9720.69 = 1.02176
Going to adjust Taiwan down, to increase South Korea and Hong Kong

Everything is bouncing around because of the US-China talks and Foxconn haven't made any friends this week:  exposure to heavy mechanisation companies and chip-fabs presses on Korea and Taiwan, because in recessions, they go first (heavy capex). All are very, very dependent on China so a victory could be pyrrhic, but if China feels the need to turn more 'China first' then Hong Kong is where it will look.

Another week has almost passed (last forecast on 23 Jan), and the current changes thus far are + 3.8%, 0.1%, 5.8% and 2.2%, so I've tweaked my estimates accordingly. Still way too much time between now and the question closing to spread the probabilities much further. Anything can (and likely will) happen between now and the end of June.

Simple update; as of today (at this moment), one week further along from my last update, Singapore is down 0.4%, Taiwan, Hang Seng and KOSPI are each up 1.3%, 1.8% and 3.1% respectively. Still a long way to the finish line, way too early to say. The dartboard is shrinking ever so slightly each week... :-)
Revising up SG at the expense of KOR after looking at whether and how price to earnings ratios have aligned with performance since 2009: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/820400
China has most chance of out-performing because of low expectations

Simple update, based on progress to date. As of 17 Jan, part way through the Asian trading day, KOSPI is up the most (+2.1%), Taiwan the least (+0.7%) and the other two in the middle (both up around +0.9%).
Still a long way to go to the finish line.... it will be fairly easy to update the odds as 28 June gets closer and the race gets a bit better established. Still a crap shoot from the point of view of this monkey throwing darts... :-)
Not basing this on much, I'm not really a finance guy. South Korea's is closer to its 52 week low than any other exchange so I think it will grow more.

Based on value investing, price to earnings ratio.Singapore Chosun and Taiwan are the most undervalued.
https://www.starcapital.de/en/research/stock-market-valuation/ Hong Kong is also the most exposed to any US-Zhongguo trade war even though all of them are also at risk.

The behaviour of financial markets is effectively random. I've spent a lot of time poring back through old North American index data and have found very little correlation, short term or long term, between information and signal. This forecast will be easy to update as time goes by and the deadline approaches. As I write this prediction, Hang Seng is down a little more than the other three (the day I make the guess), but this is just noise (which we will witness on all time scales).
south korea most oversold relative to value and less political risk versus Taiwan. hong king real estate market could   really take a dive and singapore not cheap

Base case is that higher risk will provide higher returns. HK hang seng index has the highest beta of all four and therefore gets the highest weight.  Btw, stating the obvious here but the performance should be calculated using the total return indices.

Established the base rate(s) using the following method:
1) retrieved historical closing values for the indices on the dates mentioned in the question, 1998 to 2018 (plus minus one day if a no trading day in that year)
2) determined ratio and counted years that each index 'won' Result:
For the whole timeframe, 1998-2018 (21 years) the results are: HK 3, SG 3, KOR 8, TW 7
I also thought it would be good to only look at the last 10 years, so since the last global recession. For 2009-2018 (10 years): HK 1, SG 1, KOR 3, TW 5. 
So Taiwan's winning more frequently recently, Korea is doing the about the same, and Hong Kong and Singapore won slightly less frequently recently.
So I'll start with TW 42%, KOR 34%, SG 12% and HK 12%. Adjusting: Which events could have an effect on these probabilities?
- a global recession: Taiwan won in the recession years 2008 and 2009, but in the dot com bubble burst 2000-2002, Korea won twice and Hong Kong once. 
- US-China 'trade war': signs of de-escalation will benefit Hong Kong and Taiwan, but Korea could follow in the wake.
- US tariffs in general: would negatively affect Hong Kong, Taiwan and Korea, Singapore not so much. At this point, I would give Hong Kong and Taiwan a small upward adjustment at the expense of Singapore and Korea.
Singapore is least likely to be impacted by world political affairs & to benefit from moves away from investment in China under tariffs.

Lots of geopolitical risk here, and a lot depends on the China-US trade talks. Chinese stocks are depressed as of today, taking commodities markets with them (I should know, i have some 'copper') and there are more serious shivers than usual over Taiwan, although sabre rattling has been going on for 60 years. Korea and Taiwan are highly dependent on automation and electronics groups selling into the USA so sensitive to any new US tariffs, while Korea also has major logistics companies shipping stuff from China. Singapore is a small index for companies wanting an offshore jurisdiction in Asia (the country itself only has 6 million people). The Hang Seng benefits from being the 'offshore' for big PRC companies and some Taiwanese groups that don't want to list in Taipei (which is very small). 
I am assuming there will be little real news coming out of the talks by mid year, although there may be a relief rally on the back of some cheerful-sounding PR newsbites. A bit of a 'pop' because of China-facing news, and some opportunity for a tech-related 'pop' in Korea.
Singapore is a strong economy that could benefit from a flight to safety in the event of rising trade tensions. Hong Kong & Taiwan are too linked to China.
Solution in trade war between US and China will benefit Taiwan the most, followed by Hang Seng.
